case_vignette: A 33-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of repeated episodes of severe headache for the past 3 days. He is currently having his 2nd episode of the day. He usually has his first episode in the mornings. The pain is severe and localized to his right forehead and right eye. He had similar symptoms last summer. He works as an analyst for a large hedge fund management company and spends the majority of his time at the computer. He has been under a lot of stress because of overdue paperwork. He also has chronic shoulder pain. He has been using indomethacin every 6 hours for the pain but has had no relief. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. He appears restless. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows drooping of the right eyelid, tearing of the right eye, and rhinorrhea. The right pupil is 2 mm and the left pupil is 4 mm. There is localized tenderness to his right supraspinatus muscle. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

My right eyelid is droopy, my right eye is tearing up, and I have a runny nose.

I've been taking indomethacin every 6 hours for the pain, but it hasn't helped.

I had similar symptoms last summer.
Have you recently experienced any head injury or been under unusual stress?
I've been under a lot of stress because of overdue paperwork at my job.
Do your symptoms seem to worsen after alcohol intake, lack of sleep, or certain foods?
You didn't ask me about any of those things before, so I don't have that information.
Have you noticed any triggers such as alcohol, specific foods, or lack of sleep that seem to precede your headaches?
You didn't ask me anything about triggers, so I don't have that information.
Understood. Have you had any changes in vision or experienced flashing lights?
No, I haven't mentioned anything like that.

Given the severity and location of the headaches, associated with autonomic symptoms like teary eye, drooping eyelid, and runny nose without vision changes, and considering the partial response to indomethacin, my final assessment is:

**Final Diagnosis:** Cluster Headache.
